staff.bio: Ben is a veteran developer and teacher in Brooklyn. He's taught hundreds of people to program, helped foment a revolution (ask him sometime!), and makes a mean gumbo. His work has been published in the Harvard International Review and The Best of Make Magazine, and he is totally geeking out about the phenomenal talent of the teachers below. You can see even more of his eclectic interests at techno-social.com.

Audrey is a MFA candidate in Design and Technology at Parsons in New York City. She is an experienced branding designer as well as a tech educator for children. Her current work focuses on using sensors, computer vision and Internet of Things to build multi-sensory interactive environments. See more at artificialforest.com
staff.nutshell: children's tech educator, Parsons MFA candidate

staff.bio: Ayodamola ("Ayo" for short) is an artist and interactive designer, and is currently an adjunct faculty member at The New School, Parsons School of Design. His works range from painting and speculative design to physically interactive works and explorations of Afrofuturism. See more of his work at ayo.io.
staff.nutshell: artist and interactive designer, Parsons adjunct faculty

staff.bio: Dakota (AKA "Dakota PF") is a Brooklyn-born and -based artist. As half of LOW-RES FILMS, he directs, edits, writes and designs sound for live-action and animation films. Outside of film-making, Dakota also paints and creates digital design work, and teaches kids karate.
staff.nutshell: veteran animator, director, and karate teacher

staff.bio: Taylor is a tech educator with a background in technical theatre and 3D design software. She is currently a PhD candidate at NYU Performance Studies, with a research focus in online community building. Taylor's computer course experience includes Achievement First Endeavor Middle School, NYU Magnet game center, and the Arvada Center for the Arts and Humanities.
staff.nutshell: PhD candidate at NYU and veteran tech educator

staff.bio: Bryn is a data engineer at an advertising technology company and holds a Master's in Computer Science. She has prior experience teaching introductory programming courses to first year college students, but loves younger children, especially her own niece and nephew. She lives with her husband and rescue dog named Franklyn in Clinton Hill and enjoys biking and Pixar movies.
staff.nutshell: data engineer, CS MS, dog lover

staff.bio: Katya is a postdoc in economics at Columbia University, an upcoming instructor at Girls Who Code in NYC 2016, akd a co-organizer of Pyladies NYC. She also volunteers as a dance teacher in Harlem schools and has danced ballet professinally. See more on her site.

Chris is an experienced game designer, web developer, and project manager that grew up in New York. He's trained and taught kung fu to people of all ages for 13 years at the USA Shaolin Temple. He also enjoys traveling and walking up mountains in the middle of the night.

Hilary works at the Huffington Post, where she reports, designs and develops data stories and multimedia features. She has also worked with kids through Sierra Club NYC ICO, Camp/Interactive, and more.
staff.nutshell: data journalist and designer at Huffington Post

staff.bio: James has worked on many bestselling and award-winning games, from smash hit Two Dots to his acclaimed "mobile musical" Peter Panic, produced with Broadway and game design legends. He holds an MFA in game design from Tisch, won “Best Game” award at the 2015 Global Game Jam, and been published on several popular game-related websites.

Pierre is a software developer who grew up in Europe and settled in New York to complete a Masters in Game Design. He is currently working as a freelancer for multiple companies in the tech and arts world and is an adjunct faculty member at NYU. He also volunteers for the afterschool program ScriptEd, and is eager to introduce kids to Processing/p5, Arduino and creating games!
staff.nutshell: adjunct faculty member, NYU Game Center

faquestions.q: What makes Ada & Leo different from other programs?
aParagraphs: Our guiding philosophy has been to encourage direct experience with real materials and the real creative process whenever possible, which sometimes means not having as impressive a final product as some other programs might, and also means making kids a little more frustrated than other programs might.

Everything we do, we try to aim to primarily influence the experience of the students after they finish the class. often that means giving them a fun and rewarding experience with tools inside the class, because play and joy are so crucial to developing creative power. But a class where the teacher did all the work and dazzled the kids would be one I would consider something of a failure, even if the kids felt perfectly happy. whereas a class where kids came out of it and obsessively used even just one single tool they learned in the class to create dozens of their own creations would be one I would consider a huge success.

The same goes for working through problems. Students often feel frustrated in my class and want me to fix the problem for them. Knowing each kid in their situation and their needs, sometimes I do fix it!  I'm not been absolutist about these things :). But ideally, I will just encourage the student to keep trying to figure it out themselves,  express my support, and give them a tiny push in the right direction. I believe strongly that a problem they solve themselves is worth 10 problems we solve for them, though of course in practice it's often not really that simple!

testimonials.quote: J. is playing hooky from school today, but she does not want to play hooky from her creative tech class!
testimonials.person: Brian R., parent of 6 year old girl

testimonials.quote: M. LOVED the first class yesterday. He was so excited about it!
testimonials.person: Marisa K., parent of 6 year old boy

testimonials.quote: A. *LOVES* the class. I'm excited to find her [Tinkercad project]. And now I know she can play further and do other projects there. We'll check it out more later this week! Thank YOU.
testimonials.person: Jenny D., parent of 6 year old girl

testimonials.quote: R. is really enjoying his tech classes. He asked us why normal school was not as much fun...
testimonials.person: Vin S., parent of 6 year old boy
Elizabeth G., parent of 7 year old boy

testimonials.quote: My daughter has taken this class twice now, last fall and this past winter. I thought I would have trouble getting her up on Saturday mornings, but I never did. She enjoyed Ben's class so very much and couldn't stop talking about all the things she learned once class was over.
testimonials.person: Marsha-Stephanie B., parent of 7 year old girl

testimonials.quote: Ben opened my eyes to help me see the fun and excitement that learning can offer!
testimonials.person: Arian H., former student and now MS-Ed candidate

testimonials.quote: Ben was infinitely patient and helpful!
testimonials.person: Anonymous feedback from an adult programming student
